defs.docs:
`ExponentialBackoff` is a backoff implementation that increases the backoff
 period for each retry attempt using a randomization function that grows exponentially.

attributes.value: / `ExponentialBackoff` is a backoff implementation that increases the backoff
/ period for each retry attempt using a randomization function that grows exponentially.
/ [`next_backoff`] is calculated using the following formula:
/      retry_interval * (random value in range [1 - randomization_factor, 1 + randomization_factor])
/ In other words [`next_backoff`] will range between the randomization factor
/ percentage below and above the retry interval.
/ For example, given the following parameters:
/ the actual backoff period used in the next retry attempt will range between 1 and 3 seconds,
/ multiplied by the exponential, that is, between 2 and 6 seconds.
/ **Note**: `max_interval` caps the `retry_interval` and not the randomized interval.
/ If the time elapsed since an [`ExponentialBackoff`](type.ExponentialBackoff.html) instance is created goes past the
/ The elapsed time can be reset by calling [`reset`].
/ Example: Given the following default arguments, for 10 tries the sequence will be,
/ and assuming we go over the `max_elapsed_time` on the 10th try:
/ Permanent errors are not retried. You have to wrap your error value explicitly
/             // Permanent errors need to be explicitly constructed.
/             // Transient errors can be constructed with the ? operator
/             // or with the try! macro. No explicit conversion needed
/ Transient errors can be constructed by wrapping your error value into `Error::transient`.
/ By using the ? operator or the `try!` macro, you always get transient errors.
/ You can also construct transient errors that are retried after a given
/     Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 1.54 secs
/     Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.0 secs
/ Please set either the `tokio` or `async-std` features in Cargo.toml to enable the async support of this library, i.e.:
/ A `Future<Output = Result<T, backoff::Error<E>>` can be easily retried:
/ - `tokio`: enables support for the [tokio](https://crates.io/crates/tokio) async runtime, implies `futures`,
/ - `async-std`: enables support for the [async-std](https://crates.io/crates/async-std) async runtime, implies `futures`,

defs.name: RANDOMIZATION_FACTOR
defs.docs:
The default randomization factor (0.5 which results in a random period ranging between 50%
 below and 50% above the retry interval).

defs.name: Permanent
defs.docs:
Permanent means that it's impossible to execute the operation
 successfully. This error is immediately returned from `retry()`.

attributes.value: / Permanent means that it's impossible to execute the operation
/ successfully. This error is immediately returned from `retry()`.

defs.name: Transient
defs.docs:
Transient means that the error is temporary. If the `retry_after` is `None`
 the operation should be retried according to the backoff policy, else after
 the specified duration. Useful for handling ratelimits like a HTTP 429 response.

attributes.value: / Transient means that the error is temporary. If the `retry_after` is `None`
/ the operation should be retried according to the backoff policy, else after
/ the specified duration. Useful for handling ratelimits like a HTTP 429 response.

 result.

defs.name: retry_after
defs.docs:
Creates a transient error which is retried after the specified duration.
 Useful for handling ratelimits like a HTTP 429 response.

attributes.value: / Creates a transient error which is retried after the specified duration.
/ Useful for handling ratelimits like a HTTP 429 response.

defs.name: retry
defs.value:
pub fn retry<I, E, Fn, Fut, B>(B, Fn)
-> Retry</*impl Trait*/, B, NoopNotify, Fn, Fut> where B: Backoff, Fn: FnMut()
-> Fut, Fut: Future<Output = Result<I, Error<E>>>
defs.docs:
Retries given `operation` according to the [`Backoff`] policy
 [`Backoff`] is reset before it is used.
 The returned future can be spawned onto a compatible runtime.

attributes.value: / Retries given `operation` according to the [`Backoff`] policy

/ The returned future can be spawned onto a compatible runtime.
/ Only available through the `tokio` and `async-std` feature flags.
/ async fn f() -> Result<(), backoff::Error<&'static str>> {

defs.name: retry_notify
defs.value:
pub fn retry_notify<I, E, Fn, Fut, B, N>(B, Fn, N)
-> Retry</*impl Trait*/, B, N, Fn, Fut> where B: Backoff, Fn: FnMut() -> Fut,
Fut: Future<Output = Result<I, Error<E>>>, N: Notify<E>
defs.docs:
Retries given `operation` according to the [`Backoff`] policy.
 Calls `notify` on failed attempts (in case of [`Error::Transient`]).
 [`Backoff`] is reset before it is used.
 The returned future can be spawned onto a compatible runtime.

attributes.value: / Retries given `operation` according to the [`Backoff`] policy.
/ Calls `notify` on failed attempts (in case of [`Error::Transient`]).
/ [`Backoff`] is reset before it is used.
/ The returned future can be spawned onto a compatible runtime.
/ Only available through the `tokio` and `async-std` feature flags.
/ `notify` can be neither `async fn` or [`Future`]. If you need to perform some async
/ operations inside `notify`, consider using your runtimes task-spawning functionality.
/ The reason behind this is that [`Retry`] future cannot be responsible for polling
/ `notify` future, because can easily be dropped _before_ `notify` is completed.
/ So, considering the fact that most of the time no async operations are required in
/ `notify`, it's up to the caller to decide how async `notify` should be performed.
/ async fn f() -> Result<(), backoff::Error<&'static str>> {

pub fn retry<F, B, T, E>(B, F) -> Result<T, Error<E>> where F: FnMut() ->
Result<T, Error<E>>, B: Backoff
defs.docs:
Retries this operation according to the backoff policy.
 backoff is reset before it is used.

defs.name: retry_notify
defs.value:
pub fn retry_notify<F, B, N, T, E>(B, F, N) -> Result<T, Error<E>> where
F: FnMut() -> Result<T, Error<E>>, B: Backoff, N: Notify<E>
defs.docs:
Retries this operation according to the backoff policy.
 Calls notify on failed attempts (in case of transient errors).
 backoff is reset before it is used.

attributes.value: / Retries this operation according to the backoff policy.
/ Calls notify on failed attempts (in case of transient errors).
/ backoff is reset before it is used.
/ let notify = |err, dur| { println!("Error happened at {:?}: {}", dur, err); };
